verses.text: Again, someone plans to sail, about to cross through wild waves, and calls out to wood that is more fragile than the boat itself.
verses.comment: The 'wood' here refers both to the ship and to the idols (cf. Isa 44:13-17). The contrast between man’s trust in material things and true trust in God is clear.

verses.text: Driven by the desire for gain, someone crafts a vessel out of wood with wisdom, and the skill of his hands shapes it.
verses.comment: Craftsmanship and wisdom are contrasted with idolatry, suggesting that skill is only rightly ordered when serving God's will.

verses.text: But it is Your providence, Father, that guides the ship, for even on the waves, You make a way, and through the sea, a safe path.
verses.comment: God’s fatherly care extends to all aspects of life—even over the forces of nature. This paternal language foreshadows deeper revelation in the New Testament (cf. Matt 6:9).

verses.text: Showing that You can save, even if someone goes to sea with no skill.
verses.comment: Human effort is real, but salvation—here and ultimately—depends on God’s power, not man’s ability.

verses.text: It is Your will, Father, that the works of Your wisdom should not be powerless, so even people entrust their lives to a tiny piece of wood and cross raging waves safely upon a raft.
verses.comment: The 'tiny piece of wood' may subtly foreshadow later symbolism of wood as a means of salvation (see also 1 Peter 3:20-21, Noah's Ark).

verses.text: In ancient times, when arrogant giants perished, hope for the world found refuge on a raft, guided by Your hand, leaving a seed of generations to come.
verses.comment: Referencing Noah and the flood; 'hope for the world on a raft' is a clear allusion to Noah's Ark (cf. 1 Pet 3:20-21), reinforcing the idea of God's saving action through physical means.

verses.text: Blessed is the wood by which righteousness comes.
verses.comment: A remarkable foreshadowing of the Cross, drawing a typological line from Noah's Ark (salvation by wood) to Christ's crucifixion.

verses.text: But an idol made by human hands is cursed—both it and its maker; because he made it, the perishable thing and because the idol, though weak, is called god.
verses.comment: Idols and idolatry, the work of human pride and rebellion, are sharply condemned.

verses.text: For God detests the wicked and their works; what they make and the maker will be punished together.
verses.comment: Divine justice is holistic: both sinful deeds and unrepentant persons share in judgment.

verses.text: That is why idols of nations and the nations themselves shall be judged.
verses.comment: Not just individuals, but whole communities may be caught in idolatry’s web—a corporate and even ecclesial warning.

verses.text: So judgment shall come upon the idols of the Gentiles, since among God’s creation they became abominations, a snare to human souls and a trap for fools’ feet.
verses.comment: Idolatry is portrayed not just as personal failure but spiritual bondage—a theme echoed in the New Testament (Rom 1:18-23).

verses.text: The beginning of fornication was the invention of idols; from such, they entered the world, and soon they would perish.
verses.comment: Idolatry is linked with sexual immorality—showing sin’s interconnectedness. This prepares for the New Testament's warnings (1 Cor. 10:7-8).

verses.text: For neither were they from the beginning, nor shall they last forever.
verses.comment: Only God endures eternally. All idols are only temporary creations.

verses.text: For human vanity brought them into the world, and a quick end was set for them.
verses.comment: Echoes the theme of vanity—a fleeting pursuit—that pervades the wisdom tradition.

verses.text: A father, consumed by unhallowed grief for a lost child, made an image of the child now suddenly taken, and honored him as a god now among the dead, passing on secret rites and ceremonies to his family.
verses.comment: Man-made rituals, particularly those surrounding the dead, sometimes led to false belief and idolatry. This passage hints at the peril of misplaced piety.

verses.text: Over time, this impious custom grew strong and was kept as law; and idols were then worshiped by royal decrees.
verses.comment: Idolatry’s institutionalization is a warning against elevating human tradition over revealed truth (cf. Mark 7:8-9).

verses.text: When people could not honor kings face to face, because they lived far away, they sculpted their likeness from a distance, making a visible image of the king they longed to honor; so that by zeal, the absent king might receive the same devotion as if he were present.
verses.comment: This alludes to the origins of royal statuary or images. Honoring through images for remembrance is compared with the worshipful misuse that leads to idolatry.

verses.text: The excellence of the artist helped to win devotion for the one portrayed, so that men, moved by the beauty of the image, would worship even someone who was only recently honored as a man.
verses.comment: Even artistic beauty cannot justify the worship of created things; the tradition of representation can be twisted when devotion goes astray.

verses.text: This became a trap for humanity—for men, living under tyranny or desiring to please authorities, spread the worship of images everywhere.
verses.comment: Peer pressure and political authority can both lead to wide adoption of errors; this is a warning against conforming to cultures contrary to God’s law.

verses.text: Ambition of the craftsman even led those ignorant of the king to increase their worship, seeking to please the powerful away from the truth.
verses.comment: Desire for approval can replace love of truth, leading people further from God.

verses.text: Thus, the cult of wickedness grew and was kept strong by royal decree; and the carved idols began to be adored by people.
verses.comment: As sinful customs gain authority, they become established as law. Tradition itself must be judged according to truth revealed by God.

verses.text: And as if not content with wandering astray in the knowledge of God, they live in a great struggle of ignorance, calling such evils as peace.
verses.comment: Sin is sometimes disguised as peace or progress when true peace is only found in harmony with God’s will.

verses.text: They sacrifice their own children, perform secret rituals, or engage in frenzied ceremonies filled with strange customs.
verses.comment: The depravity of idolatry’s effects is exposed—linking false worship with immorality and violence. The progression of error is evident (cf. Rom. 1:21-32).

verses.text: They no longer keep their lives or their marriages pure, but each one kills another by treachery or causes pain by adultery.
verses.comment: Moral corruption always follows theological error; fidelity to God is inseparable from the ordering of one’s personal and family life.

verses.text: All things are a confusion of blood and murder, theft and deceit, corruption, unfaithfulness, uproar, lying.
verses.comment: Describes the fruits of idolatry: social chaos and every kind of sin.

verses.text: There is confusion everywhere: dishonesty, sexual immorality, disorder in marriages, adultery, and cruelty.
verses.comment: These vices are not random but directly connected to a society's rejection of the true God. The text shows a link between religious error and moral decline.

verses.text: The worship of idols, whose names must not even be spoken, is the beginning, cause, and end of all evil.
verses.comment: Idolatry is not merely one sin among others, but the mother of all sin, rupturing man’s relationship with God, and thereby ruining all else.

verses.text: For they either delight in wild celebrations, or predict false things from omens, or live out lies through perverse customs.
verses.comment: Pagan revelry and superstition are shown to be unworthy of those who know the true God.

verses.text: For by trusting in lifeless idols, people have sworn terrible oaths and expected justice from things dead.
verses.comment: Entrusting one’s fate to mere objects rather than the living God—this folly is sharply condemned.

verses.text: But both the expectation of such things and those who make them will be equally punished, because although they are called gods, they are nothing.
verses.comment: Divine justice is impartial; both the false belief and the false object are rejected.

verses.text: For God's punishment is not for the sake of the things themselves, but for those who worship them—because even the things called gods are accountable to justice, since the thoughts about idols will be judged for their wickedness.
verses.comment: Judgment is due not to the created things themselves, but to those who use them wrongly. The spiritual and mental aspect of sin is emphasized—pointing to the importance of right worship and belief.
